title: Assessment of the applicability of analytical models for blood flow prediction in reconstructive surgery
author: Drikakis D.; Milionis C.; Pal S.K.; Patel S.; Shapiro E.
journal: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Biomedical Engineering
abstract: Arterial flow in the context of plastic or reconstructive surgery is of primary importance to the successful outcome of the procedure. Analytic formulae, which are frequently used for the estimates of flow rates in these applications, introduce a number of assumptions about the geometry of the artery, the character of the flow and media properties of blood. This paper presents a computational fluid dynamics (CFD) study of a ligated artery using real geometry taken from ex vivo intraoperative angiography of an axial flap. An analytical model is derived for this case under assumptions typically made in the literature and comparisons between the CFD study and the analytical model are presented. A systematic study to evaluate the effects of the assumptions made in constructing analytical models has been conducted, showing that the most limiting assumption is that of the simplified geometry that can lead to the pressure drop being under-predicted by up to 2.65 times. title: Laser transport through thin scattering layers
author: Eze R.; Kumar S.
abstract: Many modern applications of lasers involve understanding the transport of radiation through thin layers. The interactions of continuous wave and pulsed lasers with skin in dermatological use related to surgery and cosmetic procedures are examples of such. These highly scattering thin layers in skin are best modeled by the Monte Carlo method. However, most traditional Monte Carlo models may inaccurately account for the presence of thin layers. As an example, the very thin epidermis, with its highly absorbing melanin, is known to influence the laser penetration significantly. If the Monte Carlo model is implemented without special features, then the results of the simulation will show incorrect effects of thin layers because the path length of most photons would be significantly larger than the layer thickness. As a result, the computed photon travel path length would simply not feel the presence of the layer. In this paper, we present numerical and algorithmic features for computation of radiation transport through thin layers. It is noted that, while Monte Carlo without special features smears the radiative effect of the layers, the refined technique indicates that layers have a great impact on the absorption of energy, especially if the layer properties are distinctly different from those of the adjacent layers. The results have significant implications in the study of diagnostic and therapeutic applications of lasers in biomedicine and surgery. © 2010 Optical Society of America.

title: FSI analysis of the coughing mechanism in a human trachea
author: Malvè M.; Del Palomar A.P.; López-Villalobos J.L.; Ginel A.; Doblaré M.
abstract: The main physiological function of coughing is to remove from the airways the mucus and foreign particles that enter the lungs with respirable air. However, in patients with endotracheal tubes, further surgery has to be performed to improve cough effectiveness. Thus, it is necessary to analyze how this process is carried out in healthy tracheas to suggest ways to improve its efficacy in operated patients. A finite element model of a human trachea is developed and used to analyze the deformability of the tracheal walls under coughing. The geometry of the trachea is obtained from CT of a 70-year-old male patient. A fluid structure interaction approach is used to analyze the deformation of the wall when the fluid (in this case, air) flows inside the trachea. A structured hexahedral-based grid for the tracheal walls and an unstructured tetrahedral-based mesh with coincident nodes for the fluid are used to perform the simulations with the finite element-based commercial software code (ADINA R&D Inc.). Tracheal wall is modeled as an anisotropic fiber reinforced hyperelastic solid material in which the different orientation of the fibers is introduced. The implantation of an endotracheal prosthesis is simulated. Boundary conditions for breathing and coughing are applied at the inlet and at the outlet surfaces of the fluid mesh. The collapsibility of a human trachea under breathing and coughing is shown in terms of flow patterns and wall stresses. The ability of the model to reproduce the normal breathing and coughing is proved by comparing the deformed shape of the trachea with experimental results. Moreover the implantation of an endotracheal prosthesis would be related with a decrease of coughing efficiency, as clinically seen. © 2010 Biomedical Engineering Society.

title: A patient-specific FE-based methodology to simulate prosthesis insertion during an augmentation mammoplasty
author: Lapuebla-Ferri A.; del Palomar A.P.; Herrero J.; Jiménez-Mocholí A.-J.
abstract: Breast augmentation surgery is a widespread practice for aesthetic purposes. Current techniques, however, are not able to reliably predict the desired final aspect of the breast after the intervention, whose success relies almost completely on the surgeon's skill. In this way, patient-specific methodologies capable of predicting the outcomes of such interventions are of particular interest. In this paper, a finite element biomechanical model of the breast of a female patient before an augmentation mammoplasty was generated using computer tomography images. Prosthesis insertion during surgery was simulated using the theory of finite elasticity. Hyperelastic constitutive models were considered for breast tissues and silicone implants. The deformed geometry obtained from finite element analysis was compared qualitatively and quantitatively with the real breast shape of the patient lying in supine position, with root-mean-squared errors less than 3. mm. The results indicate that the presented methodology is able to reasonably predict the aspect of the breast in an intermediate step of augmentation mammoplasty, and reveal the potential capabilities of finite element simulations for visualization and prediction purposes. However, further work is required before this methodology can be helpful in aesthetic surgery planning. © 2011 IPEM.

title: Computational mechanics of Nitinol stent grafts
author: Kleinstreuer C.; Li Z.; Basciano C.A.; Seelecke S.; Farber M.A.
abstract: A finite element analysis of tubular, diamond-shaped stent grafts under representative cyclic loading conditions for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) repair is presented. Commercial software was employed to study the mechanical behavior and fatigue performance of different materials found in commercially available stent-graft systems. Specifically, the effects of crimping, deployment, and cyclic pressure loading on stent-graft fatigue life, radial force, and wall compliances were simulated and analyzed for two types of realistic but different Nitinol materials (NITI-1 and NITI-2) and grafts (expanded polytetrafluoroethylene-ePTFE and polyethylene therephthalate-PET). The results show that NITI-1 stent has a better crimping performance than NITI-2. Under representative cyclic pressure loading, both NITI-1 and NITI-2 sealing stents are located in the safe zone of the fatigue-life diagram; however, the fatigue resistance of an NITI-1 stent is better than that of an NITI-2 stent. It was found that the two types of sealing stents do not damage a healthy neck artery. In the aneurysm section, the NITI-1&ePTFE, NITI-1&PET, and NITI-2&PET combinations were free of fatigue fracture when subjected to conditions of radial stress between 50 and 150 mmHg. In contrast, the safety factor for the NITI-2&ePFTE combination was only 0.67, which is not acceptable for proper AAA stent-graft design. In summary, a Nitinol stent with PET graft may greatly improve fatigue life, while its compliance is much lower than the NITI-ePTFE combination. © 2008 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

title: An intraoperative beta probe dedicated to glioma surgery: Design and feasibility study
author: Bonzom S.; Ménard L.; Pitre S.; Duval M.A.; Siebert R.; Palfi S.; Pinot L.; Lefebvre F.; Charon Y.
abstract: Surgery is considered as the primary therapeutic procedure for gliomas and several recent clinical studies have shown that total tumor resection is directly associated with longer survival when compared to subtotal resection. In order to refine the resection in the boundaries of gliomas, we are developing an intraoperative probe specifically dedicated to the localization of residual tumor labeled with positron emitters. The probe is designed to be compact and electrically safe in order to be directly coupled to the excision tool leading to simultaneous detection and removal of tumor tissues. It is built with clear and plastic scintillating fibers held in a closed packed annular arrangement ensheathing the excision tool. The annihilation γ ray background is eliminated by a real-time subtraction method. Validation of the technical choice and optimization of the probe geometry were performed by preliminary measurements and Monte Carlo simulations based on the MCNP-4C code and an anthropomorphic brain phantom. The theoretical probe sensitivity was found to be 82 cps/μCi/ml with a γ ray rejection efficiency of 99.6%. The expected minimum radio-tracer detectable concentration for tumors labeled with 18F-FET was 0.10 μCi/ml. When compared to the 0.29 μCi/ml average concentration in the bulk of the tumor, this result demonstrate the potential ability of the probe to define more accurately the extent of brain tumor resection. © 2007 IEEE.

title: Development and validation methodology of the Nuss procedure surgical planner
author: Rechowicz K.J.; McKenzie F.D.
abstract: Surgical planners are used to achieve the optimal outcome for surgery. They are especially desired in procedures where a positive aesthetic outcome is the primary goal, such as the Nuss procedure which is a minimally invasive surgery for correcting pectus excavatum (PE) – a congenital chest wall deformity which is characterized by a deep depression of the sternum. The Nuss procedure consists of placement of a metal bar(s) underneath the sternum, thereby forcibly changing the geometry of the ribcage. Because of the prevalence of PE and the popularity of the Nuss procedure, the demand to perform this surgery is greater than ever. Therefore, a Nuss procedure surgical planner is an invaluable planning tool ensuring an optimal physiological and aesthetic outcome. We propose the development and validation of the Nuss procedure planner. First, a generic model of the ribcage is developed. Then, the computed tomography (CT) data collected from actual patients with PE is used to create a set of patient-specific finite element models (FEM). Based on finite element analyses (FEA) a force–displacement data set is created. This data is used to train an artificial neural network (ANN) to generalize the data set. In order to evaluate the planning process, a methodology which uses an average shape of the chest for comparison with results of the Nuss procedure planner is developed. Haptic feedback and inertial tracking is also implemented. The results show that it is possible to utilize this approximation of the force–displacement model for a Nuss procedure planner and trainer. © 2013, The Society for Modeling and Simulation International. All rights reserved.

title: Stability of cervical spine after one-level corpectomy using different numbers of screws and plate systems
author: Rosli R.; Kadir M.R.A.; Kamarul T.
journal: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine
abstract: Anterior corpectomy and reconstruction using a plate with locking screws are standard procedures for the treatment of cervical spondylotic myelopathy. Although adding more screws to the construct will normally result in improved fixation stability, several issues need to be considered. Past reports have suggested that increasing the number of screws can result in the increase in spinal rigidity, decreased spine mobility, loss of bone and, possibly, screw loosening. In order to overcome this, options to have constrained, semi-constrained or hybrid screw and plate systems were later introduced. The purpose of this study is to compare the stability achieved by four and two screws using different plate systems after one-level corpectomy with placement of cage. A three-dimensional finite-element model of an intact C1-C7 segment was developed from computer tomography data sets, including the cortical bone, soft tissue and simulated corpectomy fusion at C4-C5. A spinal cage and an anterior cervical plate with different numbers of screws and plate systems were constructed to a fit one-level corpectomy of C5. Moment load of 1.0 N m was applied to the superior surface of C1, with C7 was fixed in all degrees of freedom. The kinematic stability of a two-screw plate was found to be statistically equivalent to a four-screw plate for one-level corpectomy. Thus, it can be a better option of fusion and infers comparable stability after one-level anterior cervical corpectomy, instead of a four-screw plate.© IMechE 2014.

title: Optical properties of dental restorative materials in the wavelength range 400 to 700 nm for the simulation of color perception
author: Friebel M.; Povel K.; Cappius H.-J.; Helfmann J.; Meinke M.
abstract: Aesthetic restorations require dental restorative materials to have optical properties very similar to those of the teeth. A method is developed to this end to determine the optical parameters absorption coefficient μa, scattering coefficient μs, anisotropy factor g, and effective scattering coefficient μ's of dental restorative materials. The method includes sample preparation and measurements of transmittance and reflectance in an integrating sphere spectrometer followed by inverse Monte Carlo simulations. Using this method the intrinsic optical parameters are determined for shade B2 of the light-activated composites TPH® Spectrum®, Esthet-X®, and the Ormocer® Definite® in the wavelength range 400 to 700 nm. By using the determined parameters μa, μs, and g together with an appropriate phase function, the reflectance of samples with 1-mm layer thickness and shade B2 could be predicted with a very high degree of accuracy using a forward Monte Carlo simulation. The color perception was calculated from the simulated reflectance according to the CIELAB system. We initiate the compilation of a data pool of optical parameters that in the future will enable calculation models to be used as a basis for optimization of the optical approximation of the natural tooth, and the composition of new materials and their production process. © 2009 Society of Photo-Optical Instrumentation Engineers.

title: Finite element analysis of barbed sutures in skin and tendon tissues
author: Ingle N.P.; King M.W.; Zikry M.A.
abstract: Barbed surgical sutures are a new type of knotless suture that are currently being used clinically in cosmetic and plastic surgery procedures for faster healing and better cosmesis. Clinical studies are also underway to evaluate their performance in other deep tissue applications. However, little is known about their intrinsic mechanical behavior and their interactions with surrounding tissues. The primary objective of the current study was to analyze the mechanical behavior of barbed sutures using a finite element analysis approach. First, the effect of applying a point-pressure load to the tip of the barb and measuring its effect on barb displacement was studied. Second, the effect of an applied displacement to a barb anchored either in skin or tendon material for both the suture and the surrounding tissue. The results indicate that the flexibility of the barb can be increased or decreased by changing the barb geometry. It was concluded that the barb geometry and design need to be modified for use with different types of tissue. For example, in order to achieve the best mechanical anchoring with skin tissue the barb should be more flexible compared to the one designed to work with tendon tissue. The uniqueness of this study is that it is the first to establish a virtual prototyping and designing method for barbed sutures. For example, a new and improved virtual design of barb geometry is proposed and validated. It also provides the first report on how to develop a virtual bench top suture/tissue pullout testing environment. © 2009 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

title: Endoscopic surgery simulation in a virtual environment
author: Dumay A.C.M.; Jense G.J.
abstract: The minimally invasive nature of endoscopic surgery allows operations to be performed on patients through small incisions, often under local anaesthesia. Patient recovery times and cosmetic detriment are thus greatly reduced, while overall quality of care is improved. Presently, surgeons are trained to perform endosurgical procedures in a number of ways: practising with surgical training devices, using animal models and assisting experienced surgeons. In this paper, the focus is on answering the key question: "Can virtual environment technology assist surgeons in training and maintaining endoscopic surgery skills?" Initial developments towards surgical simulators have clearly demonstrated the great potential of virtual environment technology for surgical training purposes. Breakthroughs towards surgery are expected within the next 5 to 10 years. © 1995.

title: Modeling the thermal response of porcine cartilage to laser irradiation
author: Diaz S.H.; Aguilar G.; Lavernia E.J.; Wong B.J.F.
journal: IEEE Journal on Selected Topics in Quantum Electronics
abstract: During laser irradiation of biological tissue, a number of physical processes take place that determine temperature elevation and thermal damage rates. Some of those important to laser-tissue interaction are: 1) propagation of light in scattering media; 2) transformation of laser light into photochemical, acoustic, or thermal energy; 3) tissue-tissue and tissue-environment heat and mass transfer; 4) and the occurrence of low-energy phase transformations responsible for structural alterations. The aim of this study was to formulate a finite-element model (FEM) able to predict the temperature distribution in a slab of porcine nasal cartilage during laser irradiation. The FEM incorporates heat diffusion, light propagation in tissue, and water evaporation from the surfaces of the slab. Numerical results were compared to experimental temperature distributions where surface and internal temperatures were measured while heating cartilage using a pulsed Nd : YAG laser (λ = 1.32 μm). Rectangular specimens, 1-4-mm thick, were secured perpendicular to the laser beam and irradiated for 1-15 s using different laser-beam powers (1-10 W).

title: Non-invasive 3-D patient registration for image-guided skull base surgery
author: Westermann B.; Hauser R.
abstract: Image-guided, computer-assisted surgery systems require a common reference between the preoperative image data and the corresponding patient pathology. Therefore, the problem of an accurate and reliable 3-D patient registration and referencing has to be solved. Considering that during image data acquisition patient misalignment and movement can arise in three dimensions, an automatic image registration method must be based on a three-dimensional approach. The method presented in this paper provides accurate 3-D patient registration for correction of these movement errors during data acquisition and active patient referencing to update the position of the head during surgery. Experimental data concerning the accuracy of repeated positionings of our patient registration and reference system demonstrated a high degree of accuracy with mean spatial errors of 0.82 mm ± 0.31 mm in a plastic skull and 1.56 ± 0.76 mm in patients, respectively. Results suggest that non-invasive 3-D patient registration for image-guided surgery may be a precise and useful method for computer-assisted identification of anatomical structures. title: A biomechanical model of Peyronie's disease
author: Gefen A.; Chen J.; Elad D.
abstract: Peyronie's disease is a pathological condition of the penis which is characterized by localized ossification of the tunica albuginea. A common symptom of the chronic stage is penile deformity during erection, which is frequently associated with pain and erectile dysfunction. A two-dimensional biomechanical model of the penis was applied to study the development of Peyronie's disease by simulating the mechanical stress distribution which would result from the interaction of the ossified tunical tissue with other penile soft tissues. The model was solved by using commercial finite element software for a characteristic erectile pressure. The results demonstrate that Peyronie's plaques may induce intensified stresses around the penile nerves and blood vessels, up to double those in the normal penis. These elevated stresses may cause a painful sensation of neural origin or ischemia in regions of compressed vascular tissue. Severe penile deformities have been shown to develop if Peyronie's plaques develop only around one of the corpora cavernosa due to the non-homogeneous resistance of the tunica to expansion during erection. The present model can be clinically applied as an aid in the planning process of reconstructive surgery or insertion of a prosthesis. Copyright (C) 2000 Elsevier Science Ltd.

title: Evaluation of achievable registration accuracy of the femur during minimally invasive total hip treatment
author: Popescu F.C.; Viceconti M.; Traina F.; Toni A.
journal: Medical and Biological Engineering and Computing
abstract: The aim of the paper was to investigate whether accurate, point-based registration of the intra-operative femur will be achieved within the context of minimally invasive surgery for total hip replacement. Computer tomography images, collected for pre-operative planning purposes, were used to simulate the intra-operative registration procedure using algorithms for various levels of measurement noise, different small areas of the femur available to the surgeon, and a limited number of collected data points (20-60). This helped with the choice of design variables to perform in vitro registration on a plastic bone model to validate the procedure, which included a multistart algorithm developed for intra-operative registration. The algorithm minimised the distance between the measured and image-derived surfaces and was able to cope with the presence of multiple local minima given sufficient computational effort, even with realistically large measurement noise. It was found that, if a small patch of the femur was used, accessible by a needle that could at times penetrate thin layers of soft tissue, errors in the order of 1.0 mm in translation and 0.5° in rotation were achievable. © IFMBE: 2005.

title: High Speed Bone-Cutting and Jointing Simulation Using Run Coordinate Data
author: Suto Y.
journal: Japanese Journal of Medical Electronics and Biological Engineering
abstract: A study of three-dimensional image display in the medical field has been developed by the application of advanced computergraphics and CAD/CAM. Three-dimensional display techniqes have a wide range of medical applications, of which preoperative planning is typical. In this study, we have developed a preoperative simulation system by applying three-dimensional image processing techniques. A variety of such techniques is necessary for preoperative simulation. In this case, we have developed a simulation system for bone-cutting and jointing and have applied it to the preoperative planning for the plastic surgery. Rapidity of processing is also essential, and this has been achieved by the employment of data compression techniques, based on run coordinate data. © 1989, Japanese Society for Medical and Biological Engineering. title: A statistical wisp model and pseudophysical approaches for interactive hairstyle generation
author: Choe B.; Ko H.-S.
journal: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: This paper presents an interactive technique that produces static hairstyles by generating individual hair strands of the desired shape and color, subject to the presence of gravity and collisions. A variety of hairstyles can be generated by adjusting the wisp parameters, while the deformation is solved efficiently, accounting for the effects of gravity and collisions. Wisps are generated employing statistical approaches. Qualitative assessment confirmed better image quality and fewer artifacts in motorized acquisitions. title: Experimental and numerical assessment of two reconstructive techniques for the fragility fractures of the pelvis type Ia
author: Soliman A.; Kedziora S.; Kelm J.; Maas S.; Gerich T.
abstract: Fragility fractures of the pelvis (FFP) type Ia are characterized by an isolated anterior pelvic ring fracture without displacement. Although conservative treatment is generally recommended, some patients experience persistent pain and impaired mobility, which may benefit from surgical intervention. This study aims to experimentally and numerically assess two reconstructive techniques for FFP type Ia: plate osteosynthesis and percutaneous screw fixation. Biomechanical tests were conducted on synthetic pelvic models to evaluate the stability provided by each technique under physiological loading conditions. Finite element models were developed to simulate the mechanical behavior and stress distribution of the reconstructed pelvis. Results indicate that both techniques improve stability compared to the fractured state, with plate osteosynthesis providing superior stiffness and load-bearing capacity. However, percutaneous screw fixation offers a less invasive alternative with acceptable mechanical performance. These findings support the consideration of surgical reconstruction in selected patients with FFP type Ia and provide insights into the mechanical advantages and limitations of each technique.

abstract: Purpose: Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common skin cancer worldwide. Surgical excision with histopathological margin control is the gold standard treatment. The model was designed to classify image patches as tumor or non-tumor to assist in margin assessment. abstract: Hydroxyapatite (HA) and bioactive glass (BG) coatings on fiber reinforced composites (FRC) are promising for bone implant applications due to their bioactivity and mechanical properties. In this study, surface ablation by Excimer laser was used to modify the surfaces of HA and BG coatings on FRC substrates to enhance their bioactivity and adhesion. The laser treatment induced surface roughness and microstructural changes, which were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), atomic force microscopy (AFM), and X-ray diffraction (XRD). The bioactivity of the laser-treated surfaces was evaluated by immersion in simulated body fluid (SBF), showing enhanced apatite formation compared to untreated samples. Mechanical testing demonstrated improved interfacial bonding strength between the coatings and the FRC substrates after laser ablation. These findings suggest that Excimer laser surface ablation is an effective method to improve the performance of HA and BG coatings on FRC implants for bone tissue engineering applications.

title: Quantitative comparison of three rat models of Achilles tendon injury: A multidisciplinary approach

This study aimed to quantitatively compare three commonly used rat models of Achilles tendon injury: partial transection, full transection with suture repair, and collagenase-induced injury. Using a multidisciplinary approach, we assessed the structural, mechanical, and histological properties of the tendons at multiple time points post-injury. title: Computation of breast ptosis from 3D surface scans of the female torso
author: Li D.; Cheong A.; Reece G.P.; Crosby M.A.; Fingeret M.C.; Merchant F.A.
abstract: Breast ptosis is a common condition that is characterized by the downward displacement of the breast tissue and nipple relative to the chest wall. Accurate quantification of breast ptosis is important for clinical assessment, surgical planning, and outcome evaluation in breast surgery. Traditional methods for assessing breast ptosis rely on manual measurements and subjective grading scales, which can be inconsistent and lack precision. In this study, we present a novel computational approach to quantify breast ptosis using three-dimensional (3D) surface scans of the female torso. Our method involves the extraction of anatomical landmarks and the computation of ptosis indices based on the spatial relationships between these landmarks on the 3D breast surface. We validate our approach on a dataset of 3D scans from a diverse cohort of female subjects and demonstrate its accuracy and reproducibility compared to conventional assessment methods. The proposed computational framework offers an objective, non-invasive, and efficient tool for the evaluation of breast ptosis, with potential applications in clinical practice and research.

title: Surgical soundtracks: automatic acoustic augmentation of surgical procedures
author: Matinfar S.; Nasseri M.A.; Eck U.; Kowalsky M.; Roodaki H.; Navab N.; Lohmann C.P.; Maier M.; Navab N.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose: Surgical procedures are often accompanied by characteristic sounds, which can provide useful information about the surgical workflow and the current surgical phase. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to automatically augment surgical procedures with acoustic feedback, which can support surgeons by providing additional information through sound. Methods: We present a system that captures and analyzes surgical sounds in real time and generates corresponding acoustic augmentations. The system uses machine learning techniques to classify surgical phases based on audio features extracted from the recorded sounds. Results: We evaluated our approach on a dataset of recorded surgical procedures and demonstrated that the system can accurately recognize surgical phases and generate meaningful acoustic feedback. The acoustic augmentation was shown to improve the awareness of the surgical workflow and potentially enhance surgical performance. Conclusion: Our work introduces a new paradigm of using sound as an informative and supportive modality in the operating room. The proposed system can serve as a foundation for further research on acoustic augmentation in surgery and its integration into surgical training and practice.

title: Exploring the in vitro and in vivo compatibility of PLA, PLA/GNP and PLA/CNT-COOH biodegradable nanocomposites: Prospects for tendon and ligament applications

abstract: The development of biodegradable nanocomposites with enhanced mechanical and biological properties is crucial for tendon and ligament tissue engineering. This study investigates the in vitro and in vivo compatibility of polylactic acid (PLA) and its nanocomposites reinforced with graphene nanoplatelets (GNP) and carboxyl-functionalized carbon nanotubes (CNT-COOH). The nanocomposites were characterized for their physicochemical properties, and their cytocompatibility was assessed using human tenocytes. In vivo biocompatibility was evaluated through subcutaneous implantation in a rat model. Results demonstrated that the incorporation of GNP and CNT-COOH improved the mechanical strength and supported tenocyte proliferation without inducing cytotoxicity. Histological analysis revealed minimal inflammatory response and favorable tissue integration for all materials, with PLA/CNT-COOH showing the most promising outcomes. These findings suggest that PLA-based nanocomposites, particularly those containing CNT-COOH, hold significant potential for tendon and ligament repair applications.

Additionally, patient-specific 3D printed models facilitate better communication among surgical teams and with patients. title: Autologous bilayered self-assembled skin substitutes (Sasss) as permanent grafts: A case series of 14 severely burned patients indicating clinical effectiveness

abstract: Autologous bilayered self-assembled skin substitutes (SASSs) have been developed as permanent skin grafts for the treatment of severe burns. The SASSs were produced from the patients’ own cells without the use of scaffolds, resulting in a bilayered skin substitute composed of a stratified epidermis and a dermal layer. The grafts were applied to full-thickness wounds and followed up for up to 12 months. The results showed successful graft take, restoration of skin integrity, and satisfactory aesthetic and functional outcomes. This case series supports the potential of autologous bilayered SASSs as a viable permanent skin substitute for burn patients, offering an alternative to conventional skin grafts and engineered skin products.

title: Bladder wall biomechanics: A comprehensive study on fresh porcine urinary bladder
author: Jokandan M.S.; Ajalloueian F.; Edinger M.; Stubbe P.R.; Baldursdottir S.; Chronakis I.S.
journal: Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials
abstract: The urinary bladder is a hollow organ with a complex multilayered wall structure that undergoes large deformations during filling and voiding. Understanding the biomechanical behavior of the bladder wall is essential for the development of realistic computational models and for improving clinical treatments of bladder dysfunctions. This study presents a comprehensive experimental characterization of the mechanical properties of fresh porcine urinary bladder tissue. Uniaxial and biaxial tensile tests were performed on samples harvested from different bladder regions to capture the anisotropic and nonlinear behavior of the tissue. Histological analysis was conducted to correlate the mechanical response with the microstructural organization of collagen and smooth muscle fibers. The results reveal significant regional variations in stiffness and anisotropy, highlighting the importance of considering spatial heterogeneity in bladder wall modeling. Constitutive models were calibrated to the experimental data, providing a robust framework for simulating bladder mechanics under physiological conditions. This work contributes valuable data and insights for the design of biomimetic materials and the advancement of bladder tissue engineering.

title: Automatic detection of perforator vessels using infrared thermography in reconstructive surgery
author: Unger M.; Markfort M.; Halama D.; Chalopin C.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose: Perforator flaps are widely used in reconstructive surgery. The identification of perforator vessels is crucial for flap design and surgical planning. Infrared thermography (IRT) is a non-invasive imaging technique that can detect skin temperature variations related to underlying blood flow. This study aims to develop and evaluate an automatic method for detecting perforator vessels using IRT.  Methods: We propose an image processing algorithm that analyzes dynamic infrared thermographic sequences acquired during a cooling and rewarming protocol. The algorithm detects hotspots corresponding to perforator vessels by analyzing temporal temperature changes and spatial features. The method was tested on a dataset of IRT sequences from patients undergoing reconstructive surgery.  Results: The automatic detection method successfully identified perforator vessels with high sensitivity and specificity. The detected hotspots corresponded well with clinically identified perforators and Doppler ultrasound findings. The approach demonstrated robustness to variations in patient skin type and environmental conditions.  Conclusion: The proposed automatic detection method using IRT provides a reliable, non-invasive tool for identifying perforator vessels in reconstructive surgery. This technique has the potential to improve surgical planning and outcomes by facilitating accurate and efficient perforator mapping.

title: Reconstruction of large mandibular defects using autologous tissues generated from in vivo bioreactors

abstract: Reconstruction of large mandibular defects remains a significant clinical challenge due to the complex anatomy and functional requirements of the mandible. By implanting customized scaffolds into well-vascularized muscle sites, we harness the body's regenerative capacity to grow vascularized bone and soft tissue constructs that can be transplanted to repair mandibular defects. Our results demonstrate successful generation of viable, vascularized bone tissue with appropriate mechanical properties and integration potential. This approach offers a promising alternative for reconstructing large mandibular defects, potentially improving functional and aesthetic outcomes while minimizing donor site complications.

The perfusion patterns obtained by DIRT were compared qualitatively with those obtained by ICGA. Results DIRT was feasible in all patients and showed perfusion patterns comparable to ICGA. title: Quantitative analysis of the patellofemoral motion pattern using semi-automatic processing of 4D CT data
author: Forsberg D.; Lindblom M.; Quick P.; Gauffin H.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose The patellofemoral joint is a complex joint with a three-dimensional motion pattern. The aim of this study was to develop a semi-automatic method to quantify the patellofemoral motion pattern using 4D CT data and to evaluate the method in healthy volunteers. Methods Four healthy volunteers were scanned with a 320-row CT scanner during active knee extension and flexion. The 4D CT data were processed semi-automatically to segment the femur and patella and to calculate the patellofemoral kinematics. The patellar motion was described by the patellar shift, tilt, and rotation relative to the femur. Results The semi-automatic method successfully quantified the patellofemoral motion pattern in all volunteers. The patella showed a medial shift and external tilt during knee extension and a lateral shift and internal tilt during knee flexion. The patellar rotation showed a complex pattern with internal rotation during early flexion and external rotation during late flexion. Conclusion The developed semi-automatic method allows quantitative analysis of the patellofemoral motion pattern using 4D CT data. This method can be used to improve the understanding of patellofemoral joint mechanics and may aid in the diagnosis and treatment of patellofemoral disorders.

abstract: Magnesium (Mg) alloys are promising biodegradable materials for orthopedic implants. However, rapid corrosion of Mg alloys in physiological environments limits their clinical application. Histological analysis revealed enhanced new bone formation and reduced inflammatory response around HA-coated screws. Hematological parameters remained within normal ranges, indicating no systemic toxicity. These results suggest that HA coating effectively improves the corrosion resistance and biocompatibility of resorbable Mg alloy screws, making them promising candidates for orthopedic applications.

abstract: Limb reconstruction following segmental bone loss remains a significant clinical challenge. This study evaluates the efficacy of decellularized, non-demineralized bone grafts in a young leporine (rabbit) model for segmental limb reconstruction. Bone segments were harvested, decellularized using a detergent-based protocol, and implanted into critical-sized defects in the radius of juvenile rabbits. Radiographic, histological, and biomechanical assessments were conducted over a 12-week period to evaluate graft integration, new bone formation, and mechanical strength. Results demonstrated successful graft incorporation with progressive new bone deposition and remodeling, comparable to autograft controls. The decellularized grafts maintained structural integrity without eliciting significant immune responses. These findings suggest that decellularized, non-demineralized bone grafts are a viable option for limb reconstruction in young patients, potentially reducing donor site morbidity and improving clinical outcomes.

title: Repair of acute traumatic soft tissue defects of foot with artificial dermis in 14 cases

abstract: Objective To investigate the clinical effect of artificial dermis in repairing acute traumatic soft tissue defects of foot. Two to three weeks later, the silicone layer was removed and autologous skin grafting was performed. Results All wounds healed well without infection or necrosis. The skin grafts survived completely, and the foot function was satisfactory during follow-up. Conclusion Artificial dermis is an effective method for repairing acute traumatic soft tissue defects of foot, which can promote wound healing and improve the quality of skin grafting.

title: The effect of platelet rich plasma on angiogenesis in ischemic flaps in VEGFR2-luc mice
author: Sönmez T.T.; Vinogradov A.; Zor F.; Kweider N.; Lippross S.; Liehn E.A.; Naziroglu M.; Hölzle F.; Wruck C.; Pufe T.; Tohidnezhad M.
abstract: Platelet rich plasma (PRP) is widely used in regenerative medicine, but its effect on angiogenesis remains controversial. Here, we investigated the effect of PRP on angiogenesis in ischemic flaps using VEGFR2-luc transgenic mice, which express luciferase under the control of the vascular endothelial growth factor receptor 2 (VEGFR2) promoter. Ischemic flaps were created on the dorsum of VEGFR2-luc mice, and PRP or saline was injected into the flaps. Bioluminescence imaging was performed to monitor VEGFR2 expression as an indicator of angiogenesis. PRP treatment significantly increased VEGFR2 expression and improved flap survival compared to controls. Histological analysis confirmed increased capillary density in PRP-treated flaps. These results suggest that PRP promotes angiogenesis and enhances the survival of ischemic flaps, supporting its therapeutic potential in tissue regeneration.

title: Microcirculatory fraction (MCFI) as a potential imaging marker for tumor heterogeneity in breast cancer
author: Yang X.; Mrozek E.; Lustberg M.; Jia G.; Sammet S.; Sammet C.; Shapiro C.; Knopp M.V.
abstract: Microcirculatory fraction (MCFI) is a novel imaging marker that quantifies the fraction of tumor volume with high microcirculatory blood flow. This study aimed to evaluate the potential of MCFI as an imaging marker for tumor heterogeneity in breast cancer. Dynamic contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (DCE-MRI) was performed on 30 patients with breast cancer. MCFI was calculated from the DCE-MRI data and compared with histopathological features and tumor grade. Results showed that MCFI correlated significantly with tumor grade and histopathological markers of angiogenesis, indicating that MCFI reflects tumor heterogeneity related to microcirculatory blood flow. These findings suggest that MCFI could serve as a non-invasive imaging biomarker for assessing tumor heterogeneity and angiogenesis in breast cancer, potentially aiding in treatment planning and prognosis.

title: A Technical Review of Minimally Invasive Mitral Valve Replacements

abstract: Minimally invasive mitral valve replacement (MIMVR) has emerged as an alternative to conventional sternotomy for mitral valve surgery, aiming to reduce surgical trauma and improve recovery. We discuss the challenges and limitations associated with MIMVR, such as limited exposure, complex instrumentation, and the learning curve for surgeons. Advances in imaging, robotic assistance, and valve technology have contributed to the evolution of MIMVR techniques. The review highlights the importance of a multidisciplinary approach and careful patient evaluation to optimize outcomes. Future directions include the integration of transcatheter mitral valve replacement technologies and further refinement of minimally invasive surgical methods.

title: Kinetic evaluation study on the bioactivity of silver doped hydroxyapatite-polyvinyl alcohol nanocomposites
author: Mostafa A.A.; Oudadesse H.; El Sayed M.M.H.; Kamal G.; Kamel M.; Foad E.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part A
abstract: Silver doped hydroxyapatite-polyvinyl alcohol (Ag-HAp-PVA) nanocomposites were synthesized by a simple chemical precipitation method. The prepared nanocomposites were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The bioactivity of the nanocomposites was evaluated by immersing them in simulated body fluid (SBF) for different time intervals. The formation of apatite layer on the surface of the nanocomposites was confirmed by SEM and XRD analysis. The kinetic study of apatite formation was carried out by measuring the weight gain of the samples after immersion in SBF. The results showed that the incorporation of silver ions into hydroxyapatite enhanced the bioactivity and antibacterial properties of the nanocomposites. The kinetic evaluation indicated that the apatite formation followed a pseudo-second-order kinetic model, suggesting chemisorption as the rate-limiting step. These findings demonstrate the potential of Ag-HAp-PVA nanocomposites for biomedical applications such as bone tissue engineering and implant coatings.

abstract: The present study aimed to evaluate the in vivo performance of a new biphasic calcium phosphate (BCP) bone substitute composed of hydroxyapatite (HA) and β-tricalcium phosphate (β-TCP) in a rabbit femur defect model. Histological and histomorphometric analyses were performed at 4, 8, and 12 weeks post-implantation to assess new bone formation and material resorption. The results demonstrated that the BCP bone substitute was biocompatible, osteoconductive, and gradually resorbed over time, allowing for new bone ingrowth. title: Development and assessment of a Microsoft Kinect based system for imaging the breast in three dimensions
author: Wheat J.S.; Choppin S.; Goyal A.
abstract: Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Early detection is crucial for effective treatment and improved survival rates. Current imaging modalities such as mammography and ultrasound have limitations including discomfort, radiation exposure, and operator dependency. This study presents the development and assessment of a novel, low-cost, non-invasive system for three-dimensional (3D) imaging of the breast using the Microsoft Kinect sensor. The system captures depth data to reconstruct the breast surface in 3D, enabling volumetric measurements and shape analysis. Validation was performed using breast phantoms and clinical data from volunteers. Results demonstrate that the Kinect-based system provides accurate and reproducible 3D breast images, with potential applications in breast cancer screening, surgical planning, and monitoring of treatment response. The system offers a promising alternative to conventional imaging techniques, combining affordability, ease of use, and patient comfort.

title: Hair removal methods: A comparative study for dermoscopy images
author: Abbas Q.; Celebi M.E.; García I.F.
abstract: Hair removal is an important preprocessing step in dermoscopy image analysis. The presence of hair in dermoscopy images can significantly affect the performance of automated lesion segmentation and classification algorithms. In this paper, we present a comparative study of different hair removal methods applied to dermoscopy images. We evaluate the performance of these methods based on their ability to remove hair while preserving lesion details. The methods compared include DullRazor, morphological closing, and inpainting techniques. Our results show that inpainting methods provide better hair removal with less distortion of lesion features, which is crucial for accurate diagnosis. This study provides valuable insights for selecting appropriate hair removal techniques in dermoscopy image analysis.

title: Transplantation of reconstructed corneal layer composed of corneal epithelium and fibroblasts on a lyophilized amniotic membrane to severely alkali-burned cornea
author: Jang I.-K.; Ahn J.-I.; Shin J.-S.; Kwon Y.-S.; Ryu Y.-H.; Lee J.-K.; Park J.-K.; Song K.-Y.; Yang E.-K.; Kim J.-C.
abstract: BACKGROUND: To evaluate the efficacy of transplantation of a reconstructed corneal layer composed of corneal epithelium and fibroblasts on a lyophilized amniotic membrane (LAM) to severely alkali-burned corneas. METHODS: Corneal fibroblasts were cultured on the stromal side of LAM, and corneal epithelial cells were cultured on the epithelial side. The reconstructed corneal layer was transplanted onto the corneal surface of rabbits with severe alkali burns. The corneal surface was evaluated by slit-lamp microscopy, histology, and immunohistochemistry. RESULTS: The reconstructed corneal layer adhered well to the corneal surface and survived for at least 4 weeks. The corneal surface showed improved transparency and epithelialization compared with controls. Histological examination revealed a multilayered epithelium and stromal-like tissue beneath the epithelium. Immunohistochemical analysis showed expression of keratin 3 in the epithelium and vimentin in the fibroblast layer. CONCLUSIONS: Transplantation of a reconstructed corneal layer composed of corneal epithelium and fibroblasts on LAM promotes corneal surface reconstruction and may be a useful treatment for severe alkali-burned corneas.

journal: Medical and Biological Engineering and Computing
abstract: A telemetry system for monitoring anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) graft forces in vivo was developed and tested. The system consists of a force transducer integrated into the graft, a miniature transmitter, and an external receiver. The force transducer is a strain gauge-based device designed to measure tensile forces within the graft. The transmitter sends the force data wirelessly to the receiver, allowing real-time monitoring of graft forces during various activities. Calibration and in vitro testing demonstrated the system's accuracy and reliability. Preliminary in vivo experiments in animal models showed the feasibility of continuous graft force monitoring, providing valuable data for understanding graft biomechanics and improving surgical techniques. This telemetry system represents a significant advancement in orthopedic research and clinical practice by enabling direct measurement of ACL graft forces in living subjects.

title: Hair removal using the long-pulsed ruby laser in children
author: Morley S.; Gault D.
journal: Journal of Clinical Laser Medicine and Surgery
abstract: BACKGROUND: Hair removal in children is a common cosmetic concern. The long-pulsed ruby laser has been used effectively for hair removal in adults, but its safety and efficacy in children have not been well studied. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of the long-pulsed ruby laser for hair removal in children. METHODS: Twenty children aged 7 to 15 years with unwanted hair were treated with the long-pulsed ruby laser. Treatments were performed at 4- to 6-week intervals for a total of three to six sessions. Hair reduction was assessed by clinical examination and patient satisfaction. RESULTS: Significant hair reduction was observed in all patients, with minimal side effects. Transient erythema and mild discomfort were the most common adverse effects. No scarring or pigmentary changes were noted. CONCLUSION: The long-pulsed ruby laser is a safe and effective method for hair removal in children. It offers a promising option for pediatric patients seeking long-term hair reduction.

title: Prefabricated tracheal prosthesis with partial biodegradable materials: A surgical and tissue engineering evaluation in vivo

author: Ciapetti G.; Granchi D.; Stea S.; Cenni E.; Schiavon P.; Giuliani R.; Pizzoferrato A.
abstract: The viability and proliferation of lymphocytes obtained from silicone‐primed and control rats were assessed after in vitro re‐exposure to silicone. Cell viability was determined by trypan blue exclusion and proliferation was measured by [3H]thymidine incorporation. The results showed that lymphocytes from silicone‐primed rats had a significantly higher proliferation rate upon re‐exposure to silicone in vitro compared to controls, while cell viability remained unaffected. journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: The purpose of this study was to compare the histologic tissue response to polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) and polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) when used for vocal fold medialization in a rabbit model. Twelve rabbits underwent unilateral vocal fold medialization with either PDMS or PTFE implants. After 12 weeks, the larynges were harvested and processed for histologic evaluation. Both materials were well tolerated, with minimal inflammatory response and no evidence of implant extrusion or migration. The findings suggest that both PDMS and PTFE are biocompatible materials suitable for vocal fold medialization, with comparable histologic outcomes in this animal model.

abstract: The histological and compositional evaluations of three types of calcium phosphate cements (CPCs) were performed after implantation in subcutaneous tissue of rats immediately after mixing. The α-TCP-CaCO3 cement showed a different transformation pattern, with the formation of a carbonated apatite phase. These results suggest that the composition of CPCs influences their in vivo behavior and transformation, which is important for their clinical applications in bone repair.
